options.text: Males having colour blind father and normal mother
Females having colour blind father and normal mother
Females having colour blind father and carrier mother
Males have normal father and mother.

solution.text: Colour blindness is a recessive sex-linked trait in which the eye fails to distinguish red-green colours. The gene for normal vision is dominant. The normal gene and its recessive alleles are carried by X-chromosome. In female, colour blindness appears only when both the sex chromosomes carry the recessive gene (X<sup>c</sup>X<sup>c</sup>). The females have normal vision but function as carrier if a single recessive gene for colour blindness is present (XX<sup>c</sup>). However, in human males the defect appears in the presence of a single recessive gene (X<sup>c</sup>Y) because Y-chromosomes of males do not carry any gene for colour vision. Colour blindness, like other sex-linked trait, shows criss-cross inheritance (i.e., a male transmits his trait to his grandson through daughter, while a female transmits the traits to her grand-daughter through her son or it is transfer of trait from one sex to the offspring of the opposite sex).
